awd_titl_txt: Infrared-Radio-follow-up Observations for Detection of the Magnetic Radio Emission of Extra Solar Planets: A New Window to Detect Exoplanets and Exomoons
awd_abstract_narration:
Fatemeh Bagheri is awarded a Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (MPS-Ascend) to conduct a program of research and education at University of Texas at Arlington. Bagheri plans to use a new technique to detect “exomoons”, moons orbiting around planets near distant stars. The technique allows the detection of exoplanets and exomoons through the radio emission produced by magnetospheric processes.  Her observational approach potentially opens a new window to exoplanetary research.  Bagheri’s research efforts will involve undergraduates at a Hispanic-Serving Institution. She will also work to eliminate the known major barriers toward the inclusion of underrepresented scholars in science and engineering fields of research. 

Beyond detection of exomoons, Bagheri’s detections would also inform the extent to which the surfaces and atmospheres of exoplanets are shielded and potentially habitable. Bagheri’s research plan explores a method of detecting and measuring the magnetic fields of exoplanets via microlensing events.  She will work to break the psychological barriers to inclusion, by promoting a vision for excellence among students and training a generation of workforce with hard and soft skills.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding a planet's magnetic field is crucial as it provides valuable insights into the planet's interior dynamics, being generated by its internal dynamo. This magnetic shield plays a vital role in safeguarding potential life by deflecting harmful energetic particles away from the planet's surface. Consequently, knowledge about the magnetic fields of extrasolar planets is pivotal in evaluating their potential habitability. Currently, our understanding of planetary magnetic fields is limited to those within our solar system, excluding a variety of possible planets like hot Jupiters. Hence, the detection of even a single extrasolar planetary magnetic field could yield significant insights into the diverse nature of these distant worlds. To investigate the radio emissions of exoplanets resulting from their interaction with stellar winds, this project consists of two primary components:

  1. MHD Simulation of Exoplanet Magnetospheres: Our study delves into estimating the cross-polar cap potential (CPCP) of exoplanets under varying conditions, including changes in orbital distance, host star type, and exoplanet type (Rocky or Jovian). We also investigated the influence of tidal locking on system dynamics, revealing a significant alteration in magnetosphere-ionosphere morphology previously unexplored. The observed increase in CPCP in simulations of tidally-locked planets prompts further investigation, marking an initial step toward comprehending such star-planet systems. This finding is significant for studying the magnetospheres of close-in exoplanets, typically orbiting at distances less than 0.1 au.
  2. Roman-SKA Observation: Our research explores an alternative method for detecting exoplanets via their radio emissions, magnified by microlensing events. Based on our Monte Carolo simulation, we discovered that approximately 5% of microlensing events observed by the Nancy Roman telescope (equating to over 1300 exoplanets) could have their planetary radio emissions detected through follow-up observations with the SKA telescope in the radio band. This finding is noteworthy, given that only 210 exoplanets have been detected via microlensing events to date, primarily during caustic crossings in binary-lens events, making follow-up observations nearly impractical. Our approach considers exoplanets as companions within the source system of microlensing events, enabling feasible follow-up observations on the star-planet system. This strategy highlights the potential of infrared-radio follow-up observations to boost direct exoplanet detection rates while providing insights into exoplanetary magnetic fields and internal structures. The proposed observation strategy exhibits heightened sensitivity to detecting radio emissions from giant and close-in exoplanets, expanding our understanding of planetary responses to their space environment and evolutionary paths. Studying the magnetospheres of hot Jupiters unveils intricate interplays between magnetic fields, stellar winds, and atmospheric escape processes, enriching our comprehension of exoplanetary systems and their diverse environments.

Furthermore, utilizing the RBL model, our study identifies three hot Jupiter exoplanets—Qatar-4 b, TOI-1278 b, and WASP-173 A b—as potential candidates for detecting radio signals using the upcoming SKA telescope. Detecting radio emissions from even one hot Jupiter promises invaluable insights into planetary responses to their environments and evolutionary trajectories, shedding light on magnetic field dynamics, stellar wind interactions, and atmospheric escape mechanisms. Such knowledge significantly advances our understanding of planet formation, migration, and potential habitability beyond our solar system.

The findings from this project, detailed in three published papers, hold immense promise for the detection of Exoplanet radio emissions by ongoing and future surveys, as well as next-generation radio telescopes. Furthermore, these results lay the groundwork for future infrared-radio follow-up observations of exoplanets and exomoons using the innovative method introduced in this study. The study of magnetic fields and magnetospheric emissions of exoplanets is recognized as a frontier in scientific exploration for the next decade, as emphasized in the Origins, Worlds, and Life Planetary Science & Astrobiology Decadal Survey report.
